definitions.definition: a feeling of wanting to hurt or upset somebody

examples.text: I'm sure he only said it out of spite.
He vented his spite on his grandfather.
I felt no spite towards her.
She killed her boss's dog out of pure spite.
She was angry and full of spite.
This was her final act of spite.

definitions.definition: if you say that somebody did something in spite of a fact, you mean it is surprising that that fact did not prevent them from doing it

examples.text: In spite of his age, he still leads an active life.
They went swimming in spite of all the danger signs.
English became the official language for business **in spite of the fact that** the population was largely Chinese.

definitions.definition: if you do something in spite of yourself, you do it although you did not intend or expect to

examples.text: He fell asleep, in spite of himself.
In spite of herself, tears welled up in her eyes.

wordOrigin: Middle English: shortening of Old French despit ‘contempt’, despiter ‘show contempt for’.
